item.title: Japan Surprises With Bigger Cut to Super-Long Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan is planning to cut the issuance of super-long bonds this year by more than earlier reported as it tries to restore calm to a market spooked by recent record highs in yields.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian walks past the Ministry of Finance building in Tokyo.

item.title: Niger Junta Seizes French Nuclear Giant Orano’s Uranium Mine
item.description: Niger’s military government took control of Orano SA’s uranium mine, escalating a standoff with the French nuclear-power company.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: Orano branding.

item.title: Romania Government Talks Hit Roadblock Over Fiscal Measures
item.description: Romanian leaders hit a last-minute snag in talks to form a new government as negotiators deadlocked over how to narrow the Balkan nation’s budget deficit. The currency fell.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan, mayor of Bucharest, center, following the presidential election in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. The centrist mayor of Bucharest Nicusor Dan won Romania's presidential runoff on Sunday, quashing the ambitions of a far-right Donald Trump loyalist as voters came out in force to ensure that the Black Sea nation held steady on a pro-European path.

item.title: Thai Premier Has Few Options and Fewer Allies
item.description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra lost her second-biggest coalition partner this week, leaving her with a razor-thin majority
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai PM Visits Troops as Rivals Plan Protests for Her Ouster
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra visited troops at a border post to ease public backlash over her criticism of the army in a leaked phone call, as pro-royalist groups threatened to intensify protests demanding her resignation.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra during a meeting with soldiers at an army base near Cambodia on June 20. Source: Thailand Government Spokesman Office/AP Photo

item.title: Political Woes Could Sink Thai Economy Deeper Into Malaise
item.description: Thailand’s sudden descent into a new political crisis threatens an economy that’s already on the brink of a technical recession and bracing for the impact of the global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Hints He’ll Hold Off Iran Strike, Give Diplomacy Time
item.description: US President Donald Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to strike Iran, dialing back on recent comments that suggested military action could be imminent.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: A firefighter walks past damage at Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on June 19. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: Sanchez Puts NATO’s Trump Plan at Risk by Opposing 5% Goal
item.description: The problems piling up for Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez in Spain are threatening to spill into next week’s NATO summit, with potentially drastic consequences for the rest of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sends Warplanes Near Taiwan After US Lawmakers Visit
item.description: China sent the most warplanes toward Taiwan since October, a move that follows US lawmakers visiting a top military figure and both the UK and Japan sailing warships through the strait separating the two sides.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

item.title: Banks Face €5 Billion French Dividend Tax Bill, Senator Says
item.description: Banks in France are facing a combined tax bill of as much as €5 billion ($5.8 billion) over contentious trades allegedly designed to escape levies on dividend payments, according to a lawmaker who dubbed the process a “fraud.”
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen, Gaspard Sebag

media:content.media:description: Stock prices.

item.title: What’s Next for Canada-India Ties After G-7 Reset
item.description: The relationship between Canada and India had been strained since the Trudeau government accused New Delhi’s diplomats of backing violence and harassment against Sikh separatists living in the North American country. The dispute led to tit-for-tat expulsions of diplomatic officials.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Carney greets Modi at the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, on June 17, 2025

item.title: Rwanda Arrests Opposition Leader Over Alleged Incitement Plot
item.description: Rwandan authorities have arrested opposition leader Victoire Ingabire over an alleged plot to incite public disorder.
item.dc:creator: Ondiro Oganga

media:content.media:description: Victoire Ingabire

item.title: EU to Restrict China’s Access to Medical Device Procurements
item.description: The European Union will restrict the ability for Chinese medical device manufacturers to access public procurement contracts worth more than €5 million ($5.7 million).
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Medical device manufacturing in China.

item.title: Vietnam’s Top Leader Plans US Trip as Tariff Deadline Looms
item.description: Vietnam’s Communist Party chief To Lam is preparing to travel to the US in coming weeks as the two sides look to clinch a trade deal before President Donald Trump’s higher tariffs kick in, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

media:content.media:description: Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary To Lam.

item.title: Zichen Wang's Exit Interview From America
item.description: The popular Substacker returns home to China.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: US and Chinese flags in the entrance during trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. Talks between the US and China extended later into their second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Odd Lots: Zichen Wang’s Exit Interview from America (Podcast)
item.description: Zichen Wang is the writer of the Pekingnology newsletter, which translates important speeches and articles from China into English, and contextualizes them for Western readers. Over the past year, he’s been a master’s degree student at Princeton University, although he’s recently returned home to resume his career at a think tank in China. His stint in the US obviously came at a very interesting time, both due to the rising US-China tensions, and also the growing restrictions on Chinese students
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: UK Lawmakers Set Final Vote on Legalization of Assisted Dying
item.description: The UK’s House of Commons will hold a final vote on Friday on whether to allow assisted dying, a move that could usher in a significant cultural shift over how to handle those with terminal illnesses.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Supporters and opponents of assisted dying gather in Parliament Square to protest.

item.title: Turkey Arrests Jailed Erdogan Rival’s Lawyer, Widening Crackdown
item.description: A Turkish court arrested a lawyer of jailed Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu, intensifying a widespread crackdown on the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: The ferry terminal at Eminonu por in Istanbul, Turkey, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. Turkish markets buckled on Wednesday after the detention of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s most prominent rival, Ekrem Imamoglu, stoked concern that political upheaval risks undermining recent investor-friendly economic policies. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Russian Overnight Drone Barrage Hits Ukraine’s Kharkiv and Odesa
item.description: The cities of Odesa and Kharkiv were hit by massive Russian drone attacks overnight as Moscow continues its daily air attacks against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Firefighters tackle a blaze after a Russian attack in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in a photo released on June 20. Source: State Emergency Service of Ukraine

item.title: How Thai Political Crisis May Unfold as PM Fights to Keep Job
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra is fighting to hold on to power less than a year since taking office, after leaked comments critical of the military triggered a political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: China Says It Drove Away Philippine Ship From Disputed Shoal
item.description: China’s coast guard said it drove away a Philippine ship around Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Qianwei Zhang

media:content.media:description: A Chinese coast guard vessel near Scarborough Shoal in 2024.

item.title: Why Thailand’s Ruling Political Clan Faces a New Threat
item.description: Thailand’s most prominent political dynasty is on the brink of losing power once again. Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra is facing street protests and growing calls to resign amid mounting anger over a leaked phone call with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen, in which she criticized the Thai army for its role in a border dispute with the neighboring country.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Nhac Nguyen/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Allowed to Keep Using National Guard in LA for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump can continue to use National Guard troops to respond to protests in Los Angeles as a legal challenge over his use of the military proceeds, a federal appeals court ruled.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: California National Guard in Downtown Los Angeles. Photographer: Jim Vondruska/Getty Images

item.title: Fidelity Fund Bets on Midcaps Saying Tariff Shock Is Over
item.description: Financial markets have seen the worst of Donald Trump’s tariff threats, helping make midcap stocks an attractive buy as the outlook improves, according to a Fidelity International money manager.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson

item.title: Trump Set to Decide Within Two Weeks Whether to Strike Iran
item.description: President Donald Trump will decide within two weeks whether to strike Iran, his spokeswoman said, as Israel hit more Iranian nuclear sites and warned its attacks may bring down the leadership in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: A firefighter walks past damage at Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on June 19. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: Malaysia Court Discharges Najib From One of His 1MDB Cases
item.description: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak succeeded in setting aside another one of his court cases involving troubled state fund 1MDB, in a rare victory for the jailed politician.
item.dc:creator: Kok Leong Chan, Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Najib Razak in 2020. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Social Media Ban Moves Closer in Australia After Tech Trial
item.description: Australia’s world-first social media ban for under-16s moved closer to implementation after a key trial found that checking a user’s age is technologically possible and can be integrated into existing services.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

media:content.media:description: A focused view of individual's hands using a mobile phone indoors, conveying technology and communication concepts.

item.title: Thai Leader’s Fate Hangs in Balance as Allies Weigh Future
item.description: The political fate of Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra remains uncertain on Friday as the opposition and nationalist groups continue to pile pressure on her to quit following a leaked phone call in which she criticized her army.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra arrives for a news conference in Bangkok, on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Xi Shows No Sign of Rescuing Iran as Trump Ramps Up Pressure
item.description: China was quick to condemn Israel after its assault against Iran. Yet President Xi Jinping has shown no sign of rushing to provide weapons and other support that would help Tehran face its most critical military test in decades.
item.dc:creator: Jenni Marsh

item.title: UK Consumer Confidence Rises, Extending a ‘Fragile’ Rebound
item.description: The confidence of UK consumers improved for a second straight month, a survey found, extending a rebound that’s at risk of being derailed as war in the Middle East and higher oil prices cloud the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel
